G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7\u00a7 3 and 20.proposition: This action is brought in the Boston Housing Court pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, §§ 3 and 20, which grant the Housing Court jurisdiction over civil actions arising out of the occupation, use, and condition of residential premises and over all claims arising out of or involving the landlord–tenant relationship.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in the Boston Division of the Housing Court Department under G.L. c. 223, § 1, and G.L. c. 185C, § 3, because the Premises are located in Jamaica Plain, a neighborhood of Boston, in Suffolk County, and the cause of action arose there.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential lease includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment.

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential lease includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that G.L. c. 186, § 14 “codified a tenant’s common law rights under the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment,” and it discusses the covenant in the context of a residential lease. While the main issue is the fault standard for breach, the court clearly treats the covenant of quiet enjoyment as implied in the landlord‑tenant relationship governed by § 14, which applies to residential leases. Thus, the case supports the proposition that Massachusetts residential leases include an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 186, § 14, originally enacted in 1927, codified a tenant’s common law rights under the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment. St. 1927, c. 339, § 1. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 101-102 (1982). At common law, and as originally enacted by statute, the covenant of quiet enjoyment prohibited a landlord from wilful or intentional interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the leased premises.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284–85 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: A landlord’s failure to maintain the premises in a habitable condition, where it substantially interferes with the tenant’s use and enjoyment, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The court treats warranty of habitability and covenant of quiet enjoyment as distinct. It explicitly limits the warranty of habitability to physical conditions and, in its quiet-enjoyment analysis, focuses on the landlord’s failure to take measures to remove criminal actors from common areas, not on habitability or habitability-type conditions. While the opinion holds that serious interference with tenants’ use of common areas can breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment, it does so based on landlord inaction in controlling premises, not on failure to maintain the premises in a habitable condition. Thus, it does not frame the breach as arising from non-habitability, and the proposition overstates the link between habitability and quiet enjoyment in this case.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises. … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771, 775–76 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.proposition: A landlord’s failure to maintain the premises in a habitable condition, where it substantially interferes with the tenant’s use and enjoyment, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely involves a tenant’s counterclaim for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment based on extremely poor conditions (lack of heat, rodent and cockroach infestation, and other serious defects) and acknowledges that such a claim was established, though damages were not awarded only to avoid duplication with habitability/93A damages. While the bulk of the opinion focuses on the measure of habitability damages, the court cites Simon v. Solomon as authority and explicitly notes that the judge found a breach of quiet enjoyment in this context, which aligns with the proposition that severe habitability defects substantially interfering with use and enjoyment can constitute a breach of the covenant. The connection is somewhat indirect because the court does not elaborate doctrine on quiet enjoyment in this case, but it accepts that finding on these facts.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.relevant_excerpt: The judge also awarded Wideman the equivalent of two months’ rent on her retaliation claim under G. L. c. 186, § 18. No issue is raised as to these damages on appeal. Although the judge found a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, he awarded no damages on this claim to avoid what would have been a duplicative award. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 107-111 (1982).

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718\.proposition: Water leaks, chronic dampness, and conditions reasonably likely to cause mold or health problems may constitute substantial interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment and a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718\.support_reasoning: The case concerns noise from a cocktail lounge as a substantial interference with quiet enjoyment and a constructive eviction, not water leaks, chronic dampness, mold, or similar health-related conditions. Although it discusses the standard for a substantial deprivation of quiet enjoyment and rejects an intent requirement, it does not address moisture, leaks, or mold or construe G.L. c. 186, § 14 in that specific context. Thus it cannot be cited as direct authority for the particular proposition about water leaks and mold, even though its general reasoning about substantial interference might be analogized.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718\.relevant_excerpt: “Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable. Tenants such as these should not be left only with a claim against the proprietors of the noisome lounge.”

Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.raw_text: Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979)
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.proposition: Water leaks, chronic dampness, and conditions reasonably likely to cause mold or health problems may constitute substantial interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment and a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.support_reasoning: The case directly holds that persistent roof leaks that allow water to enter and accumulate in the tenant’s living space constitute interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and a breach of the implied warranty of habitability. While the opinion does not explicitly mention mold or health problems, the water leaks and associated dampness are the type of condition the proposition describes, so the case supports the general principle that such water-related conditions can amount to substantial interference with quiet enjoyment and a statutory violation.
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.relevant_excerpt: In addition, from May 15,1973, until at least July 20, 1976, the plaintiff’s roof leaked, causing water to enter a closet and to accumulate in the plaintiff’s living room. The judge ruled that the leaks also constituted a breach of the BHA’s implied warranty of habitability. … The judge further ruled that the leaks in the roof (but not the defective floors) interfered with the plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of the leased premises. Because of this interference, and based on his reading of G. L. c. 186, § 14, the judge ruled that the plaintiff was entitled to an additional [damages award].

Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976,.raw_text: Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976, 978 (1985)
Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976,.proposition: A landlord’s persistent failure to correct serious housing defects after notice, especially those affecting health and safety, can amount to an unlawful interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976,.support_reasoning: The excerpt shows the case involves serious housing defects, Sanitary Code violations, and a counterclaim for breach of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, but the quoted portion focuses on damages, rent abatement, c. 93A liability, and treble damages. It does not articulate or apply a legal standard that links a landlord’s persistent failure to repair serious defects after notice specifically to "unlawful interference with quiet enjoyment" under § 14. Any support for that proposition would have to come from portions of the opinion not provided here, so on this record the case does not clearly support the stated proposition.
Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976,.relevant_excerpt: “The judge’s award based on a wilful or knowing violation is supported by evidence that the previous tenant, who moved out in 1979, was unsuccessful in obtaining repairs and that some of the problems (leaks) had persisted for three and a half years and continued to the time of the trial in 1983. While each violation may not in itself have been wilful, e.g., the inadequate door, we think that where, as here, there were many continuing violations, some major and some minor, their cumulative effect on habitability can be considered by the trial judge in determining whether Brown’s behavior was wilful.”

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: Landlords also have statutory duties regarding the condition of residential premises under the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., and the implied warranty of habitability, recognized in Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 199–200 (1973).

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 199–200 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: Landlords also have statutory duties regarding the condition of residential premises under the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., and the implied warranty of habitability, recognized in Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 199–200 (1973).
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: The quoted concurrence squarely recognizes that landlords have obligations derived from the State Sanitary Code and describes those Code-based obligations as forming an implied contractual duty regarding the habitability/fitness of dwelling units. While Quirico, J., would ground the duty in an implied agreement to meet Code standards rather than in a broader, free‑floating warranty, he explicitly states that statutes and the State Sanitary Code impose obligations on landlords for the benefit of tenants and discusses the need to reverse the no‑duty rule. This supports the proposition that landlords have statutory duties under the State Sanitary Code and that these duties inform an implied warranty of habitability recognized in Hemingway.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “Since 1960 dwelling units have been subject to the State Sanitary Code… The Code, which has the force of law and applies throughout the Commonwealth, fixes minimum standards of fitness of structures for human habitation… It expressly places the burden on the owner to comply with the prescribed minimum physical standards for rented dwelling units… I would… hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards….”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: Substantial violations that interfere with a tenant’s use may support a finding of breach of quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion directly addresses statutory and common-law quiet enjoyment and holds that the landlord’s allowing repeated, preventable flooding that interfered with the tenant’s ability to live in the apartment constitutes interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. The court emphasizes that “quiet enjoyment” means freedom from serious interferences that impair the character and value of the premises and expressly affirms Gem’s liability under § 14 for permitting repeated flooding that interfered with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment, even though the separate damage award was vacated as duplicative.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … The water in Solomon’s apartment was a preventable situation, and one that Gem had a duty to prevent… The jury found… that the water interfered with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment of her apartment. Therefore, Gem is liable under G. L. c. 186, § 14.”

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A.proposition: Under G.L. c. 239, § 8A, and consistent with Hemingway and its progeny, a landlord’s failure to repair serious conditions within the premises that materially affect the health or safety of the occupants can justify rent abatement and other tenant remedies.

105 C.M.R. 410.500\u2013410.550.proposition: The existence of persistent leaks, water damage, and potential mold violates basic health and safety standards and deprives a tenant of a habitable dwelling, thereby undermining quiet enjoyment.
